newsitem.title: USA: USWC gasoline prices firm after bullish APIs.
newsitem.headline: USWC gasoline prices firm after bullish APIs.

text.p: U.S. West Coast spot gasoline prices firmed Tuesday, as inventories fell and shippers increased buying ahead of Thursday's pipeline scheduling deadline, brokers said.
The American Petroleum Institute (API) reported West Coast gasoline inventories at 28.8 million barrels, down 554,000 barrels for the week ended February 21.
"The inventories today were bullish," one broker said.
Spot prices gained support from March NYMEX gasoline, which climbed 0.77 cents a gallon on ACCESS, after ending the floor session 1.99 cents higher at 62.23 cents.
NYMEX crude, another influence on PADD 5 spot trade, rose 14 cents a barrel on ACCESS to $21.14 after API showed U.S. Gulf stocks off 2.9 million barrels last week.
The draw lent a bearish undertone to the total U.S. build of 516,000 barrels last week.
Bids for CARB gasoline in Los Angeles were talked two cents a gallon higher at 73.00 cents, with deals done at 73.50 cents and 73 cents Tuesday, traders said.
Conventional gasoline in L.A. was assessed between 68 and 68.50 cents a gallon, about two cents over yesterday's levels.
Buyers scrambled to buy barrels before Thursday's deadline to commit shipments on the Santa Fe Pipeline. Barrels must be set before the first barrels are sent next week, traders said.
Buying remained slack for distillates, with CARB diesel bids in L.A. falling 2.50 cents a gallon to 70.50.
